elements.content: In this work, pyridyl-appended Co3+ complexes (1 and 2) have been postfunctionalized by using 4-(bromomethyl)­benzoic acid, thus changing the functionalities from pyridyl-N donors to carboxylate-O donors. Using two such postfunctionalized metalloligands (3 and 4), several homo and heterometallic coordination polymers (HCPs) have been synthesized. Single crystal structural analyses revealed that all HCPs presented intriguing one-dimensional catenated architectures. Postsynthetic modification induced flexibility was found to be responsible for the nearly identical architectures for two sets of HCPs starting from two different postfunctionalized metalloligands, 3 and 4. Two sets of HCPs differed by the presence (3a–3d) or absence (4a–4b) of labile coordinated water molecules that demonstrated a profound effect on the heterogeneous catalysis of Knoevenagel condensation reactions and cyanation reactions.

elements.content: This work illustrates the use of two postfunctionalized metalloligands for the synthesis of several homo and heterometallic coordination polymers (HCPs) displaying intriguing one-dimensional catenated architectures. Two sets of HCPs, differing by the presence or absence of coordinated water molecules, demonstrate a profound effect on the heterogeneous catalysis of Knoevenagel condensation and cyanation reactions.

elements.content: Design and synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) are important because of their well-defined architectures and potential applications in catalysis, gas sorption, optics, magnetism, and devices. Recently, extensive efforts have been devoted to design next-generation CPs with fascinating structural features and topologies. Constructing an organized and well-designed framework material has always been a challenging task. One of the landmark achievements in this field is the utilization of a metalloligand as a well-defined building block for the construction of a desirable and ordered architecture. Today, the focus is to design improved metalloligands that can generate next-generation CPs with tunable architectures for various custom-made applications. Notably, a majority of the applications in CPs are related to the porosity such materials offer, and therefore, continuous efforts have been made to enhance their porosity. Such a feat can be achieved primarily by introducing lengthened or extended organic linkers that can coordinate to the secondary metals to afford extended architectures of increased porosity. Similarly, one could utilize metalloligands having extended appended groups to potentially coordinate secondary metal ions to generate desirable CPs with enhanced porosity. In this context, very few examples are available in the literature wherein organic ligands containing extended functional groups have been used. However, one could also think about introducing extended functional groups by the means of postsynthetic modification, an approach recently developed in CP research. In this work, efforts have been made to lengthen the appended functional groups by postsynthetic modification of already known metalloligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design and synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) are important because of their well-defined architectures and potential applications in catalysis, gas sorption, optics, magnetism, and devices. Recently, extensive efforts have been devoted to design next-generation CPs with fascinating structural features and topologies. Constructing an organized and well-designed framework material has always been a challenging task. One of the landmark achievements in this field is the utilization of a metalloligand as a well-defined building block for the construction of a desirable and ordered architecture. Today, the focus is to design improved metalloligands that can generate next-generation CPs with tunable architectures for various custom-made applications. Notably, a majority of the applications in CPs are related to the porosity such materials offer, and therefore, continuous efforts have been made to enhance their porosity. Such a feat can be achieved primarily by introducing lengthened or extended organic linkers that can coordinate to the secondary metals to afford extended architectures of increased porosity. Similarly, one could utilize metalloligands having extended appended groups to potentially coordinate secondary metal ions to generate desirable CPs with enhanced porosity. In this context, very few examples are available in the literature wherein organic ligands containing extended functional groups have been used. However, one could also think about introducing extended functional groups by the means of postsynthetic modification, an approach recently developed in CP research. In this work, efforts have been made to lengthen the appended functional groups by postsynthetic modification of already known metalloligands.

elements.content: In particular, we have used two pyridyl-appended cobalt-based metalloligands for postfunctionalized modification using 4-bromomethylbenzoic acid, thus changing the functionalities from pyridyl-N donors to carboxylate-O donors. The resultant postfunctionalized metalloligands after reaction with secondary metal ions produced one-dimensional (1D) CPs with intriguing catenated architectures, 3a–3d and 4a–4b. Postsynthetic modification approach induced flexibility has resulted in nearly identical structures of two sets of CPs starting from two different postfunctionalized metalloligands. The two sets of CPs differ by the presence (3a–3d) or absence (4a–4b) of labile coordinated water molecules, which illustrate a profound effect on the heterogeneous catalysis of Knoevenagel condensation reactions and cyanation reactions.

Postsynthetic modification approach induced flexibility has resulted in nearly identical structures of two sets of CPs starting from two different postfunctionalized metalloligands. The two sets of CPs differ by the presence (3a-3d) or absence (4a-4b) of labile coordinated water molecules, which illustrate a profound effect on the heterogeneous catalysis of Knoevenagel condensation reactions and cyanation reactions.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Commercially available reagents of analytical grade were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified using the standard literature procedures. The ligands H2L3py and H2L4py and their Co3+ complexes 1 and 2 were synthesized according to our previous report.

elements.content: FTIR spectra were recorded with a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two spectrometer having Zn–Se ATR. NMR spectral measurements were carried out with a JEOL 400 MHz spectrometer. Absorption spectra were recorded either with PerkinElmer Lambda 25 or Lambda 35 spectrophotometers. Elemental analysis data were obtained with an Elementar Analysen Systeme GmbH Vario EL III instrument. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out with a DTG 60 Shimadzu at 5 °C min–1 heating rate under a nitrogen atmosphere. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) measurements were carried out using a Thermo Scientific iCAP Q. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were performed either with an X’Pert Pro from Panalytical or a Bruker AXS D8 Discover instrument (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54184 Å) with a slow scan rate at room temperature. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area measurements were carried out by using nitrogen adsorption–desorption in an automated surface area and porosity analyzer (Quantachrome).
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

FTIR spectra were recorded with a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two spectrometer having Zn-Se ATR. NMR spectral measurements were carried out with a JEOL 400 MHz spectrometer. Absorption spectra were recorded either with PerkinElmer Lambda 25 or Lambda 35 spectrophotometers. Elemental analysis data were obtained with an Elementar Analysen Systeme GmbH Vario EL III instrument. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out with a DTG 60 Shimadzu at 5 °C min-1 heating rate under a nitrogen atmosphere. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) measurements were carried out using a Thermo Scientific iCAP Q. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were performed either with an X'Pert Pro from Panalytical or a Bruker AXS D8 Discover instrument (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54184 Å) with a slow scan rate at room temperature. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area measurements were carried out by using nitrogen adsorption-desorption in an automated surface area and porosity analyzer (Quantachrome).

elements.content: The intensity data were collected at 293 K with an Oxford XCalibur CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data were processed with XCalibur S SAINT, whereas the empirical absorption correction was applied using spherical harmonics implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR97 and refined by the full-matrix least-squares refinement techniques on F 2 using program SHELXL-97 incorporated in the WinGX version 1.70 crystallographic collective package. The solvent accessible voids (SAVs) were calculated using PLATON. Additional refinement details have been included in the Supporting Information (SI). Details of the crystallographic data collection and structure solution parameters are provided in , whereas Tables S1 and S2 contain the selected bonding parameters.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The intensity data were collected at 293 K with an Oxford XCalibur CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data were processed with XCalibur S SAINT, whereas the empirical absorption correction was applied using spherical harmonics implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR97 and refined by the full-matrix least-squares refinement techniques on F 2 using program SHELXL-97 incorporated in the WinGX version 1.70 crystallographic collective package. The solvent accessible voids (SAVs) were calculated using PLATON. Additional refinement details have been included in the Supporting Information (SI). Details of the crystallographic data collection and structure solution parameters are provided in , whereas Tables S1 and S2 contain the selected bonding parameters.

Postfunctionalized metalloligands (PFMLs) 3 and 4 were synthesized by treating pyridine-appended metalloligands 1 or 2 (as the case may be) with 4-bromomethylbenzoic acid in DMSO (). FTIR spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 showed characteristic νC=O stretches for arylcarboxylic acid at 1708 and 1707 cm–1, respectively, whereas bands at 3089 and 2927 cm–1 and 3100 and 2929 cm–1 are assigned to the C–H stretches of the methylene group for 3 and 4, respectively (Figures S1 and S2). 1H NMR spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 displayed the characteristic singlet for the methylene group (−CH2−) at 5.85 and 5.64 ppm, respectively (Figures S3 and S5). This feature confirmed that all four pyridyl groups have been functionalized. 13C NMR signals for the −CH2– group were noted at 62.8 and 61.9 for PFMLs 3 and 4, respectively (Figures S4 and S6). UV–vis spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 exhibited bathochromically shifted absorption maxima (ca. 15 and 40 nm) when compared to their parent metalloligands 1 and 2, respectively (Figures S7 and S8). This is most probably due to the incorporation of additional π-electron fragments. A close similarity between the XRPD patterns of as-synthesized PFMLs to those of simulated PFMLs from their single crystal diffraction data revealed the phase purity of the bulk samples (Figures S9 and S10). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) for PFMLs 3 and 4 was performed in the temperature ranges of 30–800 °C. TGA exhibited the loss of lattice water molecules between 30–100 °C, whereas both PFMLs were stable up to 300 °C and decayed beyond this temperature sequentially. For PFML 3, an observed weight loss (1.94%) fits with the calculated weight loss of 2.38% for the release of two water molecules (Figure S11). For PFML 4, a weight change (obsd/calcd (%); 5.14/5.21) corresponded to the loss of four lattice water molecules (Figure S12).

Results and Discussion

Design Aspects and Synthesis

Postfunctionalized metalloligands (PFMLs) 3 and 4 were synthesized by treating pyridine-appended metalloligands 1 or 2 (as the case may be) with 4-bromomethylbenzoic acid in DMSO (). FTIR spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 showed characteristic νC=O stretches for arylcarboxylic acid at 1708 and 1707 cm-1, respectively, whereas bands at 3089 and 2927 cm-1 and 3100 and 2929 cm-1 are assigned to the C-H stretches of the methylene group for 3 and 4, respectively (Figures S1 and S2). 1H NMR spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 displayed the characteristic singlet for the methylene group (-CH2-) at 5.85 and 5.64 ppm, respectively (Figures S3 and S5). This feature confirmed that all four pyridyl groups have been functionalized. 13C NMR signals for the -CH2- group were noted at 62.8 and 61.9 for PFMLs 3 and 4, respectively (Figures S4 and S6). UV-vis spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 exhibited bathochromically shifted absorption maxima (ca. 15 and 40 nm) when compared to their parent metalloligands 1 and 2, respectively (Figures S7 and S8). This is most probably due to the incorporation of additional π-electron fragments. A close similarity between the XRPD patterns of as-synthesized PFMLs to those of simulated PFMLs from their single crystal diffraction data revealed the phase purity of the bulk samples (Figures S9 and S10). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) for PFMLs 3 and 4 was performed in the temperature ranges of 30-800 °C. TGA exhibited the loss of lattice water molecules between 30-100 °C, whereas both PFMLs were stable up to 300 °C and decayed beyond this temperature sequentially. For PFML 3, an observed weight loss (1.94%) fits with the calculated weight loss of 2.38% for the release of two water molecules (Figure S11). For PFML 4, a weight change (obsd/calcd (%); 5.14/5.21) corresponded to the loss of four lattice water molecules (Figure S12).

elements.content: The two sets of HCPs were synthesized by treating PFMLs 3 and 4 with the appropriate M­(OAc)2 salt (). The crystalline HCPs, once formed, were largely insoluble in most of the common organic solvents. As the present HCPs contain two different metals (except 3b) where differentiating between such metals would be difficult solely based on the difference of their electron densities from X-ray diffraction studies, ICP-MS analyses were carried out. Indeed, ICP-MS results revealed the presence of two different metals (%) for the following HCPs as follows: 3a, Co/Mn (3.94/3.91); 3c, Co/Ni (3.82/3.85); 3d, Co/Zn (3.61/3.75); and 4a, Co/Mn (3.81/3.75). Importantly, these analyses establish the presence of two different metals in an approximately 1:1 ratio in all these HCPs.

elements.content: All six HCPs exhibited strong stretches (1625–1641 cm–1) due to the νCOO groups in their FTIR spectra. In addition, broad features at 3382–3416 cm–1 are indicative of the presence of coordinated and/or lattice water molecules (Figures S13–S18). HCPs 3a–3d, synthesized from PFML 3, displayed λmax in the range of 662–674 nm in their diffused reflectance absorption spectra (Figure S19). On the other hand, HCPs 4a and 4b, originating from PFML 4, showed λmax at 699 and 679 nm, respectively (Figure S20). In both cases, such features are tentatively assigned to the d–d transitions based on both primary (Co3+ ion) and secondary metals (except for Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions).

elements.content: XRPD patterns of the freshly prepared samples of HCPs 3a–3d as well as 4a–4b were nearly similar to those simulated from the single crystal diffraction data, which is indicative of the phase purity of the bulk samples (Figures S21–S26). To probe thermal profiles of all six HCPs, TGA studies were performed in the temperature ranges of 30–800 °C (Figures S27 and S28). For all six HCPs, a good match was observed for the weight losses between 30–120 °C corresponding to the lattice and/or coordinated water molecules, as shown in . Subsequent to the weight loss for such water molecules, all HCPs were thermally stable up to 300–325 °C. Beyond this temperature, sequential decomposition of PFMLs followed by their parent metalloligands took place (ca. 40–60%), which continues up to ca. 600 °C and finally leads to metal oxides (35–50%). Two representative HCPs, 3a and 4a, were also investigated for their porosity measurements using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) studies (Figures S29 and S30). HCP 3a and 4a respectively showed surface areas of 18.7 m2/g (average pore size: 134.5 Å) and 22.9 m2/g (average pore size: 339.4 Å). These results indicate low surface area as a result of compact packing of 1D chains in the crystal lattice (cf. crystal structures).

Both PFMLs 3 and 4 were crystallographically characterized and were found to crystallize in monoclinic cells with C2/c and P2/c space groups, respectively (for asymmetric unit, see Figure S31). X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that in both cases all four pyridyl groups were functionalized with 4-(bromomethyl)­benzoic acid and thus are present in the pyridinium form (a,d). The positive charge on the resultant PFMLs is balanced by the combinations of bromide ion(s) and anionic arylcarboxylate group(s). In the case of PFML 3, all four pyridyl-N functionalized arylcarboxylic groups are in their protonated form (i.e., COOH), whereas the parent metalloligand has a 1– charge. Therefore, overall 3+ charge is balanced by three bromide anions. Notably, one of the bromide ions lies on bisects of the plane and thereby contributes two negative charges. In contrast, in PFML 4, out of four pyridyl-N functionalized arylcarboxylic groups, two each are present in neutral protonated (i.e., COOH) and anionic deprotonated (i.e., COO–) forms. Therefore, an overall monocationic charge is balanced by a bromide ion. However, crystal structure exhibits two Br– ions with half occupancy, and thus, both of them together contribute to the 1– charge. In PFMLs, geometry of the central Co­(III) ion remained largely unaffected after the postfunctionalization of the pyridyl groups. In both cases, average Co–Npyridyl and Co–Namide bond distances were found to be in range of 1.870–1.873 and 1.970–2.010 Å, respectively (Table S1). These values are quite similar to that of our earlier cobalt-based metalloligands.

Crystal Structures

Crystal Structures of PFMLs 3 and 4 

Both PFMLs 3 and 4 were crystallographically characterized and were found to crystallize in monoclinic cells with C2/c and P2/c space groups, respectively (for asymmetric unit, see Figure S31). X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that in both cases all four pyridyl groups were functionalized with 4-(bromomethyl)benzoic acid and thus are present in the pyridinium form (a,d). The positive charge on the resultant PFMLs is balanced by the combinations of bromide ion(s) and anionic arylcarboxylate group(s). In the case of PFML 3, all four pyridyl-N functionalized arylcarboxylic groups are in their protonated form (i.e., COOH), whereas the parent metalloligand has a 1- charge. Therefore, overall 3+ charge is balanced by three bromide anions. Notably, one of the bromide ions lies on bisects of the plane and thereby contributes two negative charges. In contrast, in PFML 4, out of four pyridyl-N functionalized arylcarboxylic groups, two each are present in neutral protonated (i.e., COOH) and anionic deprotonated (i.e., COO-) forms. Therefore, an overall monocationic charge is balanced by a bromide ion. However, crystal structure exhibits two Br- ions with half occupancy, and thus, both of them together contribute to the 1- charge. In PFMLs, geometry of the central Co(III) ion remained largely unaffected after the postfunctionalization of the pyridyl groups. In both cases, average Co-Npyridyl and Co-Namide bond distances were found to be in range of 1.870-1.873 and 1.970-2.010 Å, respectively (Table S1). These values are quite similar to that of our earlier cobalt-based metalloligands.

elements.content: PFML 3 forms H-bonding-based assembly via a bromide ion, Br2, which connects two molecules through the O6–H group of the carboxylic acid (O6–H6···Br2: 2.442 Å) (b). Such an interaction generates a 1D chain. Further, such 1D chains interact with the adjacent chain through other weak interactions and finally generate a two-dimensional (2D) packing (c). In the case of PFML 4, individual molecules are connected to each other via COOH···OC­(OH) H-bonding interactions (O3–H2···O5: 1.723 Å). Such a bonding produces an overall 2D architecture manifested by H-bonding interactions and generates a square-grid architecture (e,f). The topology of the resultant H-bonded network is sql with a {44·62} point symbol (g).

Such an interaction generates a 1D chain. Further, such 1D chains interact with the adjacent chain through other weak interactions and finally generate a two-dimensional (2D) packing (c). In the case of PFML 4, individual molecules are connected to each other via COOH⋅⋅⋅OC(OH) H-bonding interactions (O3-H2⋅⋅⋅O5: 1.723 Å). Such a bonding produces an overall 2D architecture manifested by H-bonding interactions and generates a square-grid architecture (e,f). The topology of the resultant H-bonded network is sql with a {44⋅62} point symbol (g).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were carried out for all four HCPs, 3a–3d (for asymmetric unit, see Figure S32). Although all four HCPs presented a very similar 1D polymeric chain structure, 3d was different because of the absence of metal-coordinated water molecules when compared to the remaining three HCPs, 3a–3c. Therefore, crystal structures of 3a (as a representative case) and 3d are discussed in detail. HCP 3a crystallized in a monoclinic cell with the P2 1 /n space group. The asymmetric unit contains one PFML 3, one Mn­(II) ion, two coordinated water, one bromide ion, one DMSO, and 25 lattice water molecules. A 1D polymeric chain is generated via the coordination of secondary Mn­(II) ions to the arylcarboxylate fragments originating from PFML 3 (a–c). Each Mn­(II) ion exhibits six-coordinated octahedral geometry. Out of six coordination sites, four are satisfied with Ocaroxylate atoms (O5, O8, O10, and O12) coming from four different arms of two PFMLs. The remaining two axial sites are occupied by the water molecules (O1W and O2W). 1D chains are further connected to the parallel-running neighboring ones through various H-bonding interactions involving Ocarboxylate and lattice water molecules as well as C–H···π interactions to generate a 2D sheet-like architecture (d). PLATON analysis exhibited that only 2.7% solvent accessible voids (SAVs) per unit cell volume existed due to the compact packing of 1D chains. From the topological point of view, each Mn atom is connected to two PFMLs having four arms and thus can be simplified as a four-connected node, whereas each PFML can be viewed as a linear linker connecting two Mn centers (e). Therefore, the network is constituted of a 2,2,2,4-connected four-nodal net having a Schläfli symbol of {122}­{12}10{22}­{2}10. Reaction of Co­(II) and Ni­(II) ions with PFML 3 afforded HCPs 3b and 3c, and both crystallized in a triclinic cell with a P1̅ space group. The crystal structures and packing as well as topologies of HCPs 3b and 3c were nearly identical to that of 3a (Figures S33 and S34).

Each Mn(II) ion exhibits six-coordinated octahedral geometry. Out of six coordination sites, four are satisfied with Ocaroxylate atoms (O5, O8, O10, and O12) coming from four different arms of two PFMLs. The remaining two axial sites are occupied by the water molecules (O1W and O2W). 1D chains are further connected to the parallel-running neighboring ones through various H-bonding interactions involving Ocarboxylate and lattice water molecules as well as C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions to generate a 2D sheet-like architecture (d). PLATON analysis exhibited that only 2.7% solvent accessible voids (SAVs) per unit cell volume existed due to the compact packing of 1D chains. From the topological point of view, each Mn atom is connected to two PFMLs having four arms and thus can be simplified as a four-connected node, whereas each PFML can be viewed as a linear linker connecting two Mn centers (e). Therefore, the network is constituted of a 2,2,2,4-connected four-nodal net having a Schläfli symbol of {122}{12}10{22}{2}10. Reaction of Co(II) and Ni(II) ions with PFML 3 afforded HCPs 3b  and 3c, and both crystallized in a triclinic cell with a P1̅ space group. elements.content: HCP 3d, prepared by treating PFML 3 with Zn­(II) salt, crystallized in an orthorhombic cell with Pna21 space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one PFML, one Zn­(II) ion, one bromide ion, and six lattice water molecules. The Zn­(II) ion acquired tetrahedral geometry where all four coordination sites are satisfied by Ocarboxyalate groups stemming from two different PFMLs. In this case as well, a 1D polymeric chain was generated by the coordination of secondary Zn­(II) ions to the PFML 3 (a–d). Each 1D chain is further connected to the adjacent chains via H-bonding between lattice water molecules and Oamide atoms as well as via C–H···π interactions (O1···O4W: 2.764 Å; O4W···H–C59: 3.055 Å) (b). As a result, 1D chains are stacked to generate a layered structure. The crystal structure of 3d exhibits 8.4% SAVs per unit cell volume, which is filled with the lattice water molecules. Topological analysis revealed a similar network topology for 3d as observed in the case of 3a–3c.

The Zn(II) ion acquired tetrahedral geometry where all four coordination sites are satisfied by Ocarboxyalate groups stemming from two different PFMLs. In this case as well, a 1D polymeric chain was generated by the coordination of secondary Zn(II) ions to the PFML 3 (a-d). Each 1D chain is further connected to the adjacent chains via H-bonding between lattice water molecules and Oamide atoms as well as via C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions (O1⋅⋅⋅O4W: 2.764 Å; O4W⋅⋅⋅H-C59: 3.055 Å) (b). As a result, 1D chains are stacked to generate a layered structure. The crystal structure of 3d exhibits 8.4% SAVs per unit cell volume, which is filled with the lattice water molecules. Topological analysis revealed a similar network topology for 3d as observed in the case of 3a-3c.

elements.content: To understand both the effect and impact of the position of appended groups, metalloligand 2 offering para-pyridyl groups was functionalized. The resultant para-pyridyl-N functionalized PFML 4, on reaction with Mn­(II) and Cd­(II) salts, produced HCPs 4a and 4b, respectively. Both HCP 4a and 4b crystallized in a tetragonal cell with I41/a space group. In both cases, the asymmetric unit contained one-fourth of PFML 4, one secondary M­(II) ion, and two lattice water molecules (for asymmetric unit, see Figure S35). In both cases, the geometry of the secondary metal ion was nearly square antiprism, wherein all eight coordination sites were satisfied by the bidentate Ocarboxylate groups (a,c). The Mn–O bond distances were found to be in the range of 2.284–2.367 Å, whereas Cd–O bond lengths were noted between 2.411–2.416 Å (Table S1). These bonds are quite longer than those of other literature examples. A combination of PFML 4 and M­(II) ions generated 1D chains in both cases; such chains are further connected to the neighboring chains through H-bonding involving lattice water molecules as well as C–H···π interactions (d–f). Such interactions generated a 2D sheet-like packing in both cases. As expected, topological analyses revealed an identical network topology for both HCPs: a 2,2,4-connected nodal net with a point symbol of {82}­{8}6{22}­{2}6. (b,g).

The resultant para-pyridyl-N functionalized PFML 4, on reaction with Mn(II) and Cd(II) salts, produced HCPs 4a and 4b, respectively. Both HCP 4a and 4b crystallized in a tetragonal cell with I41/a space group. In both cases, the asymmetric unit contained one-fourth of PFML 4, one secondary M(II) ion, and two lattice water molecules (for asymmetric unit, see Figure S35). In both cases, the geometry of the secondary metal ion was nearly square antiprism, wherein all eight coordination sites were satisfied by the bidentate Ocarboxylate groups (a,c). These bonds are quite longer than those of other literature examples. A combination of PFML 4 and M(II) ions generated 1D chains in both cases; such chains are further connected to the neighboring chains through H-bonding involving lattice water molecules as well as C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions (d-f). Such interactions generated a 2D sheet-like packing in both cases. elements.content: Heterogeneous catalysis has made significant impact in recent time. Such a fact is due to ease in product separation and recyclability of the catalyst. In this context, CPs have been found to be quite effective as heterogeneous catalysts because of their robust architecture, porous nature, and crystallinity. Attempts have been made to incorporate assorted Lewis acid as well as redox-active metals in CPs. In this direction, our research group has successfully developed various heterogeneous catalysts for noteworthy organic transformations. The present HCPs provided a noteworthy opportunity to test their heterogeneous catalytic applications. This is due to the fact that two sets of HCPs differ by the presence (3a–3d) or absence (4a–4b) of coordinated water molecules that may have a profound effect on heterogeneous catalysis. We selected Knoevenagel condensation reactions (KCRs) and cyanation reactions (CRs) to test the said hypothesis. Both KCRs and CRs are well-established reactions for the introduction of carbon–carbon bonds via nucleophilic addition to carbonyl compounds. Both these reactions are known to be catalyzed by Lewis acid metals. However, reports are available for the utilization of bases, ionic liquids, and external stimuli, such as microwave irradiation, supersonic waves, and grinding for driving such reactions.
elements.clean_text:
Application of 3a and 4a in Heterogeneous Catalysis

Heterogeneous catalysis has made significant impact in recent time. Such a fact is due to ease in product separation and recyclability of the catalyst. In this context, CPs have been found to be quite effective as heterogeneous catalysts because of their robust architecture, porous nature, and crystallinity. Attempts have been made to incorporate assorted Lewis acid as well as redox-active metals in CPs. In this direction, our research group has successfully developed various heterogeneous catalysts for noteworthy organic transformations. The present HCPs provided a noteworthy opportunity to test their heterogeneous catalytic applications. This is due to the fact that two sets of HCPs differ by the presence (3a-3d) or absence (4a-4b) of coordinated water molecules that may have a profound effect on heterogeneous catalysis. We selected Knoevenagel condensation reactions (KCRs) and cyanation reactions (CRs) to test the said hypothesis. Both KCRs and CRs are well-established reactions for the introduction of carbon-carbon bonds via nucleophilic addition to carbonyl compounds. Both these reactions are known to be catalyzed by Lewis acid metals. However, reports are available for the utilization of bases, ionic liquids, and external stimuli, such as microwave irradiation, supersonic waves, and grinding for driving such reactions.

elements.content: For such catalytic reactions, one representative HCP from each set was selected, 3a and 4a. Both 3a and 4a have Mn­(II) ions as the secondary metals that are coordinated to Ocarboxylate atoms originating from PFMLs. Importantly, whereas the Mn­(II) ion in 3a is coordinated by two axial water molecules, 4a does not contain any coordinated solvent molecules. It is a well-known fact that the coordinated solvent molecules on a catalytic metal are often labile and thus facilitate their easy replacement and/or exchange by a suitable solvent and/or a substrate. Therefore, we investigated possible replacement and/or exchange of the coordinated water molecules in 3a. For such a purpose, a vacuum-dried (at 50 °C) sample of 3a was sealed in an atmosphere of D2O. A comparison of the FTIR spectra of as-synthesized 3a and the spectra after the D2O exchange experiment exhibited that the most of the water molecules (potentially both coordinated as well as lattice) in 3a were replaced by D2O, and such a sample exhibited νO–D stretches at ca. 2500 cm–1 (Figure S36). This simple experiment infers that the coordinated water molecules in 3a are labile, and a suitable solvent can potentially replace them.

elements.content: To further explore possible replacement of the labile water molecules by a potential substrate, benzaldehyde was selected along with HCP 3a, as a representative case. For such an experiment, vacuum-dried (at 50 °C) sample of 3a was dipped in a CH2Cl2 solution of benzaldehyde. This impregnated sample was then investigated by FTIR spectrum that showed red-shifted stretches for the aldehyde group (1696 cm–1) compared to neat benzaldehyde (1707 cm–1). This experiment strongly suggests that benzaldehyde has potentially substituted the coordinated water molecule in HCP 3a (Figure S37).

elements.content: We started with CRs of benzaldehyde for exploring the catalytic efficiencies of the present HCPs. For optimizing the reaction conditions, 3a was used as a representative catalyst along with benzaldehyde as a model substrate and trimethylsilyl cyanide as the cyanide source (). Such reactions were performed at 25 °C using only 1 mol % of a catalyst and were completed within 2 h. As can be seen, quantitative product was noted under the solvent-free condition (entry 5) when compared to the use of various solvents (35–54%; entries 1–4). Under the identical reaction conditions, HCP 4a resulted in 68% product formation (entry 6).

Reaction conditions: catalyst: 1 mol %; reaction time: 2 h; temperature: 25 °C.

With these optimized reaction conditions, catalytic scope was investigated. To understand the effect of an electronic group present on the benzaldehyde, assorted substituted aldehydes were used (). Notably, CRs were quite effective both with electron-rich and electron-deficient benzaldehydes when compared to benzaldehyde (entries 1–6). However, the electronic group effect was much more pronounced with 2-nitro-benzaldehyde because of the anticipated −R effect of the nitro group (entry 2). Although bulkier naphthaldehyde produced nearly quantitative product with HCP 3a (entry 8), a much lower yield was noted with 2,4,6-trimethoxybenzaldehyde as a substantially sterically hindered substrate (entry 8).

Subsequently, HCPs 3a and 4a were used as the heterogeneous catalysts for KCRs ( and ). In these reactions, an aldehyde substrate was treated with malononitrile at 40 °C in the presence of only 1 mol % of HCPs as the catalyst. A screening of various solvents suggested that quantitative results are obtained under the solvent-free condition (entry 5; ); however, use of MeCN (entry 1) and toluene (entry 4) also produced the corresponding product in high yield. To explore the scope of catalysis, different aldehydes containing electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups were used (). As anticipated, former substrates resulted in increased product formation (entries 2–4) when compared to para-methoxy benzaldehyde (entry 5). Use of 1-naphthaldehyde produced the respective product in good yield (entry 6) with HCP 3a when compared to the sterically demanding substrate, 2,4,6-trimethoxybenzaldehyde (entry 7).

A comparison of catalytic results both for CRs and KCRs illustrate that HCP 3a is a much efficient catalyst when compared to 4a. The crystal structures have confirmed that whereas the Mn­(II) ion in 3a is coordinated by two axial water molecules, 4a does not contain any coordinated solvent molecule. In addition, the Mn­(II) ion in 4a exhibits an eight-coordinated geometry wherein a metal is symmetrically surrounded by eight Ocarboxylate groups and does not have any open and/or vacant site. These facts strongly suggest that although a substrate may not have difficulty in accessing the Lewis acid metal ions in 3a, in contrast, 4a does not provide substrate accessibility. Furthermore, D2O and benzaldehyde exchange experiments asserted the labile nature of coordinated water molecules in 3a. Further evidence came from the time-dependent reaction profile between benzaldehyde and (CH3)3SiCN using HCPs 3a (blue trace) and 4a (red trace) as the catalysts under the solvent-free condition (). This experiment explicitly distinguishes between HCPs 3a and 4a and proves the better catalytic efficiency of 3a when compared to 4a, justifying the aforementioned points.

elements.content: It is desirable for a heterogeneous catalyst to exhibit both recyclability and reusability. For such a purpose, HCP 3a was selected as a representative catalyst for performing a filtration test during the KCR between benzaldehyde and malononitrile. As can be seen from , the catalytic reaction is nearly ceased when HCP 3a was removed from the reaction mixture by filtration at 2 h. The readdition of 3a at 3 h resulted in the immediate commencement of the catalysis. These observations potentially suggest that the actual catalytic metal sites have not leached out from HCPs during the catalysis. Additional evidence came from the recyclability studies, in which HCP 3a was filtered from the reaction mixture and was reused for five consecutive cycles for a reaction between benzaldehyde and malononitrile (inset; ). Although a drop in the product yield was negligible for the first three cycles, a 5–6% decrease in the product yield was noted at the fourth and fifth cycles.
elements.clean_text:
Heterogeneous Nature of Catalysis and Reusability

It is desirable for a heterogeneous catalyst to exhibit both recyclability and reusability. For such a purpose, HCP 3a was selected as a representative catalyst for performing a filtration test during the KCR between benzaldehyde and malononitrile. As can be seen from , the catalytic reaction is nearly ceased when HCP 3a was removed from the reaction mixture by filtration at 2 h. The readdition of 3a at 3 h resulted in the immediate commencement of the catalysis. These observations potentially suggest that the actual catalytic metal sites have not leached out from HCPs during the catalysis. Additional evidence came from the recyclability studies, in which HCP 3a was filtered from the reaction mixture and was reused for five consecutive cycles for a reaction between benzaldehyde and malononitrile (inset; ). Although a drop in the product yield was negligible for the first three cycles, a 5-6% decrease in the product yield was noted at the fourth and fifth cycles.

Inset displays recyclability of HCP 3a for five consecutive catalytic cycles.

elements.content: Taking advantage of the heterogeneous nature of catalysis, both HCPs 3a and 4a were recovered from the reaction mixture of a KCR of benzaldehyde with malononitrile and characterized. The sample homogeneity of 3a and 4a was confirmed by the XRPD studies. XRPD patterns, both for 3a and 4a, exhibited a nearly identical match to that of as-synthesized samples, suggesting that the crystallinity of the HCPs is maintained during the catalysis (Figures S38 and S39). Similarly, FTIR spectra of the recovered HCPs 3a and 4a after the catalysis overlapped nicely to that of pristine HCPs, thus further confirming structural stability during the catalysis (Figures S40 and S41).

elements.content: In this work, two different postfunctionalized metalloligands (PFMLs 3 and 4) have been utilized for the synthesis of 1D HCPs, 3a–3d and 4a–4b. These chain-like HCPs illustrated intriguing catenated architectures and differed by the presence (3a–3d) or absence (4a–4b) of coordinated water molecules. The secondary metals of HCPs derived from PFML 3 displayed six-coordinated geometry with two axially coordinated water molecules. In contrast, PFML 4 derived HCPs showed saturated eight-coordinated geometry of the secondary metals with no ligated solvent molecule. Representative HCPs 3a and 4a were utilized as heterogeneous catalysts for carrying out cyanation reactions and Knoevenagel condensation reactions and illustrated a profound effect of the presence of labile water molecules on the secondary metals on catalysis. These catalytic results are noteworthy and will help in designing better heterogeneous catalysts. The present design strategy has provided a noteworthy alternate procedure to synthesize postfunctionalized metalloligands having extended functional groups. It is believed that such a design strategy will help in preparing desirable architectures offering open structures for various porosity related applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, two different postfunctionalized metalloligands (PFMLs 3 and 4) have been utilized for the synthesis of 1D HCPs, 3a-3d and 4a-4b. These chain-like HCPs illustrated intriguing catenated architectures and differed by the presence (3a-3d) or absence (4a-4b) of coordinated water molecules. The secondary metals of HCPs derived from PFML 3 displayed six-coordinated geometry with two axially coordinated water molecules. In contrast, PFML 4 derived HCPs showed saturated eight-coordinated geometry of the secondary metals with no ligated solvent molecule. Representative HCPs 3a and 4a were utilized as heterogeneous catalysts for carrying out cyanation reactions and Knoevenagel condensation reactions and illustrated a profound effect of the presence of labile water molecules on the secondary metals on catalysis. These catalytic results are noteworthy and will help in designing better heterogeneous catalysts. The present design strategy has provided a noteworthy alternate procedure to synthesize postfunctionalized metalloligands having extended functional groups. It is believed that such a design strategy will help in preparing desirable architectures offering open structures for various porosity related applications.

cln_elements.content:
Postfunctionalized metalloligands (PFMLs) 3 and 4 were synthesized by treating pyridine-appended metalloligands 1 or 2 (as the case may be) with 4-bromomethylbenzoic acid in DMSO (). FTIR spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 showed characteristic νC=O stretches for arylcarboxylic acid at 1708 and 1707 cm–1, respectively, whereas bands at 3089 and 2927 cm–1 and 3100 and 2929 cm–1 are assigned to the C–H stretches of the methylene group for 3 and 4, respectively (Figures S1 and S2). 1H NMR spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 displayed the characteristic singlet for the methylene group (−CH2−) at 5.85 and 5.64 ppm, respectively (Figures S3 and S5). This feature confirmed that all four pyridyl groups have been functionalized. 13C NMR signals for the −CH2– group were noted at 62.8 and 61.9 for PFMLs 3 and 4, respectively (Figures S4 and S6). UV–vis spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 exhibited bathochromically shifted absorption maxima (ca. 15 and 40 nm) when compared to their parent metalloligands 1 and 2, respectively (Figures S7 and S8). This is most probably due to the incorporation of additional π-electron fragments. A close similarity between the XRPD patterns of as-synthesized PFMLs to those of simulated PFMLs from their single crystal diffraction data revealed the phase purity of the bulk samples (Figures S9 and S10). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) for PFMLs 3 and 4 was performed in the temperature ranges of 30–800 °C. TGA exhibited the loss of lattice water molecules between 30–100 °C, whereas both PFMLs were stable up to 300 °C and decayed beyond this temperature sequentially. For PFML 3, an observed weight loss (1.94%) fits with the calculated weight loss of 2.38% for the release of two water molecules (Figure S11). For PFML 4, a weight change (obsd/calcd (%); 5.14/5.21) corresponded to the loss of four lattice water molecules (Figure S12).

XRPD patterns of the freshly prepared samples of HCPs 3a–3d as well as 4a–4b were nearly similar to those simulated from the single crystal diffraction data, which is indicative of the phase purity of the bulk samples (Figures S21–S26). To probe thermal profiles of all six HCPs, TGA studies were performed in the temperature ranges of 30–800 °C (Figures S27 and S28). For all six HCPs, a good match was observed for the weight losses between 30–120 °C corresponding to the lattice and/or coordinated water molecules, as shown in . Subsequent to the weight loss for such water molecules, all HCPs were thermally stable up to 300–325 °C. Beyond this temperature, sequential decomposition of PFMLs followed by their parent metalloligands took place (ca. 40–60%), which continues up to ca. 600 °C and finally leads to metal oxides (35–50%). Two representative HCPs, 3a and 4a, were also investigated for their porosity measurements using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) studies (Figures S29 and S30). HCP 3a and 4a respectively showed surface areas of 18.7 m2/g (average pore size: 134.5 Å) and 22.9 m2/g (average pore size: 339.4 Å). These results indicate low surface area as a result of compact packing of 1D chains in the crystal lattice (cf. crystal structures).

HCP 3d, prepared by treating PFML 3 with Zn­(II) salt, crystallized in an orthorhombic cell with Pna21 space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one PFML, one Zn­(II) ion, one bromide ion, and six lattice water molecules. The Zn­(II) ion acquired tetrahedral geometry where all four coordination sites are satisfied by Ocarboxyalate groups stemming from two different PFMLs. In this case as well, a 1D polymeric chain was generated by the coordination of secondary Zn­(II) ions to the PFML 3 (a–d). Each 1D chain is further connected to the adjacent chains via H-bonding between lattice water molecules and Oamide atoms as well as via C–H···π interactions (O1···O4W: 2.764 Å; O4W···H–C59: 3.055 Å) (b). As a result, 1D chains are stacked to generate a layered structure. The crystal structure of 3d exhibits 8.4% SAVs per unit cell volume, which is filled with the lattice water molecules. Topological analysis revealed a similar network topology for 3d as observed in the case of 3a–3c.

Crystal data of 3b: cell = triclinic; space group = P1̅; a = 12.8413(6); b = 15.3364(7); c = 21.9533(10); α = 90.5190(10); β = 98.0160(10); γ = 111.4980(10); V = 3974.9(3); Z = 2.

Crystal data of 3c: cell = triclinic; space group = P1̅; a = 13.045(3); b = 15.4065(17); c = 22.128(2); α = 89.370(8); β = 82.555(11); γ = 67.901(14); V = 4082.4(10); Z = 2.

Design Aspects and Synthesis

This feature confirmed that all four pyridyl groups have been functionalized. 13C NMR signals for the -CH2- group were noted at 62.8 and 61.9 for PFMLs 3 and 4, respectively (Figures S4 and S6). UV-vis spectra of PFMLs 3 and 4 exhibited bathochromically shifted absorption maxima (ca. 15 and 40 nm) when compared to their parent metalloligands 1 and 2, respectively (Figures S7 and S8). This is most probably due to the incorporation of additional π-electron fragments. For PFML 4, a weight change (obsd/calcd (%); 5.14/5.21) corresponded to the loss of four lattice water molecules (Figure S12).
